trial_identification.scientifictitle: A Randomized Controlled Trial of Tai Chi for Depression

conditions.healthcondition: Mental health including depression, anxiety and stress

interventions.interventions:
Group A participants attended an intensive instructor-led tai chi/qigong exercise group-based training (3 sessions per week) during the first 6 months of intervention, followed by a less intensive training (1 session per week) during the following 6 months. Group B participants were placed on a waiting list during the first 6 months, followed by intensive instructor-led group tai chi/qigong training (3 sessions per week) during the second 6 months. All participants continued their treatment as usual during the study.
The exercise was adapted from the KaiMai tai chi style. Each group session lasted 1 to 1.5 hours with 10 minutes warm up, 45 minutes practice, and 10 to 25 minutes cooling down. The intensity of the exercise during each session varied among participants according to individual health and fitness levels.
The treatment as usual refers to that study participants continued to receive usual medical care from their doctors during the study period.
interventions.comparator: Treatment as usual (participants continued to receive usual care from their doctors during the study period). Group B participants will be placed on a waiting list before commencing the intervention during the second 6 months.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Depressive symptoms (assessed by CES-D10 and Depression Anxiety Stress Scale 21 [DASS21]).
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at induction screening, randomization baseline, and then at 3, 6, 9 and 12 months.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Anxiety (assessed by Depression Anxiety Stress Scale 21 [DASS21]).
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at induction screening, randomization baseline, and then at 3, 6, 9 and 12 months.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Stress symptoms (assessed by Depression Anxiety Stress Scale 21 [DASS21]).
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at induction screening, randomization baseline, and then at 3, 6, 9 and 12 months.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Quality of life, assessed using the Medical Outcomes Study 36-Item Short-Form Health Survey.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at induction screening, randomization baseline, and then at 3, 6, 9 and 12 months

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Leg strength, assessed using a chair-stand test (number of stands completed in 30 seconds) modified from the US Senior Fitness Test (after the fasting blood measures test).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at induction screening, randomization baseline, and then at 3, 6, 9 and 12 months.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Body mass index, calculated using the formula: Body mass index = weight (kg) / height (m)2.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at induction screening, randomization baseline, and then at 3, 6, 9 and 12 months.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Waist circumference. The assessor stood in front of the participant Wo correctly locate the narrowing of the waist. The measurement was taken with an anthropometry measurement tape at the level of the narrowest point over the naked skin between the lower costal (rib) border and the iliac crest. Waist circumference was measured three times for each participant and results were recorded. The mean of the three measurements was taken as the final result.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at induction screening, randomization baseline, and then at 3, 6, 9 and 12 months.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Blood pressure, each participant rested for at least 5 minutes prior to measurement, in a chair with their back supported. The left arm was bared and supported at heart level. The cuff was firmly wrapped around the left upper arm (or around the right upper arm if the first blood collection was conducted on the right arm) at heart level, measured three times for each participant and results were recorded. The mean of the three measurements was taken as the final result.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at induction screening, randomization baseline, and then at 3, 6, 9 and 12 months.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Fasting blood glucose. Blood samples were obtained from each participants antecubital vein after an overnight fast for the determination of plasma glucose at the Princess Alexandra Hospital in Brisbane, Queensland, Australia.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at induction screening, randomization baseline, and then at 3, 6, 9 and 12 months.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Fasting blood insulin. Blood samples were obtained from each participants antecubital vein after an overnight fast for the determination of serum insulin at the Princess Alexandra Hospital in Brisbane, Queensland, Australia.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at induction screening, randomization baseline, and then at 3, 6, 9 and 12 months.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: HbA1c. Blood samples were obtained from each participants antecubital vein after an overnight fast for the determination of HbA1c at the Princess Alexandra Hospital in Brisbane, Queensland, Australia.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at induction screening, randomization baseline, and then at 3, 6, 9 and 12 months.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Lipids. Blood samples were obtained from each participants antecubital vein after an overnight fast for the determination of lipids at the Princess Alexandra Hospital in Brisbane, Queensland, Australia.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at induction screening, randomization baseline, and then at 3, 6, 9 and 12 months.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Eligibility criteria included age 18-80 years, depression (identified by GPs), being on antidepressants for depression or having a short form Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale 10 (CESD 10) rating score of 10 or higher, and having central obesity assessed by waist circumference (> 95 cm [men]; 80 cm [women]) and/or body mass index (> 30 kg/m2) using the definition of central obesity by the International Diabetes Federation.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Exclusion criteria included contraindications to physical activity, mental illness other than depression, such as diagnosed bipolar disorder and schizophrenia, severe or acute general medical problem, type 1 diabetes, current pregnancy, being within 3 months post-partum, or anticipating pregnancy during the course of the study.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The primary purpose of the study was to determine the effects of a tai chi/qigong exercise intervention program on variables associated with mental health, quality of life, leg strength and selected metabolic parameters in participants with depression and central obesity.
